title: Could I demand all the documents from Junk Debt Buyer in Court?
question: Dear Experts,
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Bankruptcy court,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Fraud,Sued for debt,Evidence,State court
answers: I would add that if you hire trial counsel, they may also be able to convince the court to continue the trial date, especially if there's been no continuance before and the lawyer needs time to prepare. Another reason you would stand a good chance at a continuance is that courts would much rather have prepared attorneys try a matter than self-represented parties.

If you believe that you owe the debt, liability or whatever they are suing you for and you think you might lose at trial, you may consider filing for bankruptcy before a judgment is entered against you. This is because after a judgment is entered against you, if you file for bankruptcy, the creditor can file a lawsuit against you in bankruptcy trying to get their debt out of bankruptcy. If there was a prior state court proceeding and a fraud judgment, the bankruptcy court won't re-litigate the merits of the issue and as a result you may be out of luck. By filing before a judgment is entered against you, it is much harder for the same creditor to prove fraud in the bankruptcy court (which they must in order to win) because its a tougher standard to win on.

I would consider hiring an experienced trial attorney first (if you don't already have one), which can get expensive if they know what they are doing, and simultaneously consult with a bankruptcy attorney to evaluate your options right away.

I agree with Attorney Chen, if I were you I would hire a lawyer and that may be enough to convince the court to allow you to reopen discovery and get the information to prove your case! Don't risk losing your case because you don't know the law and will get out-lawyered by the other side!

You don't indicate when the trial is set for. I suspect it is too late to conduct written discovery. It is unlikely the court will grant a trial continuance just because you did not pursue discovery.

As an alternative to discovery, if your case is a limited jurisdiction case, I suggest that you serve a Request for Statement of Witnesses and Evidence (Form DISC-015):

http://www.courts.ca.gov/documents/disc015.pdf

Any party may serve a Request for Statement of Witnesses and Evidence (Form DISC-015) no more than 45 days or less than 30 days prior to the date first set for trial.
